awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Scalable and Topologically Versatile Material Point Methods for Complex Materials in Multiphysics Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational simulation of natural phenomena is a ubiquitous tool in the natural sciences (environmental modeling, prediction of earthquakes or avalanches), bio-mechanics (modeling the musculoskeletal system, organ function, or tissue damage), manufacturing (product design, prototyping, and verification) as well as in computer graphics/animation. This project advances the science of simulation using a technique called Material Point Methods (MPM), by increasing the number of materials and range of phenomena that can be simulated, and optimizing the performance of numerical algorithms used for simulations at larger scales. The enhancements from this project will enable studies in terrain dynamics, design and prototyping of vehicles and agricultural implements interacting with complex soils, modeling of material failure and fracture scenarios including biological settings such as skin tearing, surgical incisions, or vascular rupture. The optimization and scaling will allow computational studies of simulated physical systems at levels of resolution that were previously only afforded to large enterprises.

This project extends MPM simulation to: a) materials with multi-phase interactions influenced by thermodynamics; and b) media with complex multi-scale geometric features, including porosity (e.g. water-soil interactions) or aggregates dominated by grains of non-spherical geometry. This project extends MPM simulation to phenomena that include intricate frictional contact (beyond the no-slip contact model embedded in traditional MPM), dynamic crack propagation, and de-cohesion. This research thread leverages the team's prior work on non-manifold data structures for storing implicit geometry representations, allowing the background grids of MPM to incorporate a richer set of topological features (e.g. tears and incisions) than those incorporated by conventional array-based regular lattices. Finally, this research boosts the scale of MPM simulations that can be accommodated in modern multiprocessors, improving detail, resolution as well as parallel efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The recently concluded NSF project, focusing on the "Scalable and Topologically Versatile Material Point Methods for Complex Materials in Multiphysics Simulation," stands as a testament to the remarkable intersection of computational and physical sciences. Throughout its tenure, the project has achieved significant advancements in computational models, numerical algorithms, and parallel software engineering that have revolutionized the capabilities of Material Point Methods (MPM).


The project has been a cornerstone for innovation in computational science, distinguished by its intellectual contributions that have pushed the boundaries of simulation and modeling capabilities. At the heart of these advancements lies a series of cutting-edge algorithmic developments and computational frameworks that have significantly advanced the state of the art. A pivotal achievement of the project was the formulation and implementation of a GPU-accelerated algorithm tailored for hyperelastic simulations. This algorithm leveraged the advanced capabilities of modern GPUs, allowing researchers to execute simulations with unparalleled speed, robustness, and scale. The success of this development hinged on the intricate mathematical models that underpinned the algorithm, ensuring precision in simulations that are especially collision-intensive. The project's ingenuity birthed a sophisticated four-layer distributed simulation system, which was engineered with meticulous attention to detail to enhance the efficiency of Material Point Methods (MPM). This system set a new precedent for computational scalability, facilitating the execution of simulations at a gigascale level. Such a leap in computational ability was instrumental in broadening the applicability of MPM across various high-performance computing platforms.


Expanding the scope of MPM, the project also delved into the Lagrangian solid-fluid coupling, pioneering a unified two-way coupling methodology. This innovation significantly uplifted the precision of simulations dealing with the intricate interactions between nonlinear hyperelastic objects and fluids, marking a milestone in the simulation of complex multiphysics phenomena. Beyond these core computational enhancements, the project triumphed in simulating the nuanced behaviors of materials under stress. The development of "AnisoMPM" was particularly noteworthy, enabling the accurate portrayal of anisotropic damage mechanics and the propagation of fractures, both brittle and ductile. This was complemented by the crafting of optimization-based integrators, which allowed simulations to proceed with larger time steps while maintaining fidelity, thereby streamlining the process of elastodynamics simulations. The treatment of frictional contact also witnessed significant progress, with new mathematical formulations that empowered optimization-based time integrators to model the interactions between solids with exceptional efficiency and accuracy. These advances in frictional contact mechanics have implications across various applications, from engineering design to predictive modeling in natural phenomena.


The versatility of the project's MPM solver became particularly evident in its application to earth and environmental sciences. It played a crucial role in modeling and understanding environmental hazards such as iceberg calving and the genesis of tsunamis, directly contributing to the body of knowledge related to global warming and environmental change. In the field of robotics, the project's sensitivity analysis and MPM capabilities facilitated the design of bistable mechanisms on soft robots, an effort that was recognized with a best paper award at a leading robotics conference.


The project's influence extended into the domain of computational physics and high-performance computing (HPC), where GPU-based algorithms designed by the project team found broader application. These contributions have not only bolstered the computational infrastructure within scientific computing but have also provided tools that are now integral to the study and simulation of solid structural mechanics in metals and biomechanical materials. Moreover, the project's commitment to open-source practices has accelerated technology transfer, with software products being made widely available. This has democratized access to advanced simulation tools, thereby fostering innovation and further research within the broader scientific and industrial communities. The project's multidisciplinary impact was also vividly displayed in its contributions to the fields of mechanical engineering, civil and structural engineering, aerospace engineering, geophysics, environmental science, and computer graphics.
